conclusion: To solve the problem, analyze the P-V diagram of the Stirling cycle and determine the relationship between the states and the thermal motion of gas molecules.
The image shows a P-V diagram of a Stirling cycle starting at state A and transitioning through states B, C, and D before returning to state A. Processes A→B and C→D are isothermal.
The Stirling cycle consists of four main processes: A→B, B→C, C→D, and D→A. Processes A→B and C→D are isothermal.
Process B→C is an adiabatic expansion, meaning the system does not exchange heat with surroundings. During adiabatic expansion, temperature decreases.
When transitioning from state B to state C, adiabatic expansion results in a decrease in temperature, making thermal motion of gas molecules less intense.
The thermal motion of gas molecules becomes less intense when transitioning from state B to state C.
